title: Organic farming - WELS (Waterpedia Environmental Learning Series)

tasks.task: Understand organic farming practices compared to conventional methods.
subtasks: Learn about the historical context of organic farming (used by humans for 100,000 years before Industrial Revolution).
Recognize the goal of organic farming to be more sustainable and environmentally friendly.
Identify the prohibition of chemical fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides in organic farming.
Understand the use of natural alternatives like manure and crop rotation in organic farming.
Acknowledge the lower crop yields in organic farming due to less control over mineral content and more labor-intensive methods.
Compare organic farming's approach to weed control versus conventional methods.
Recognize the potential benefits of organic farming for biodiversity and ecosystem health.
Understand the market pricing advantage of organic products due to perceived higher quality.

tasks.task: Identify the drawbacks and challenges of organic farming.
subtasks: Understand the higher costs associated with organic farming methods.
Recognize the limitations in specialty crop production due to labor-intensive practices.
Consider the potential limitations in feed additives for livestock in organic farming.
Acknowledge the potential for nutrient imbalances in soil without chemical fertilizers.
Understand the impact of switching to organic farming on local biodiversity and ecosystem changes.

tasks.task: Reflect on the debate between organic and conventional farming.
subtasks: Compare the environmental impacts of organic and conventional farming methods.
Consider the role of organic farming in addressing climate change and sustainability.
Weigh the economic factors influencing the adoption of organic farming practices.
Analyze the potential trade-offs between yield, cost, and environmental impact in modern agriculture.
